Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Bacterial-symbiont-mediated competitive interactions among entomopathogenic nematodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The negative effects of individual species of parasites on animals have been intensively studied and can be very strong. Many animals are infested by multiple species of parasites, some of which have symbiotic microorganisms, but we know relatively little about how the interactions between parasites and their symbionts within a host may reduce or exacerbate the effects of parasitism. This project will investigate the interactions between two species of nematodes that parasitize insects and a bacterial symbiont of one of these species. Researchers will infect an insect host with nematodes, bacteria, or both to test the effect of the bacteria on the ability of the nematodes to reproduce. To investigate the underlying mechanisms, chemicals produced within the host in the different treatments will be compared for ability to induce responses in the bacteria and to inhibit the growth of the parasites. The results will broaden our knowledge of the role of parasites in natural systems and how they affect the health of animals.

Previous studies have shown that bacteria within a host can influence the performance of parasites and even prevent them from successfully reproducing. This project will add to this promising new avenue for preventing or controlling parasitism. Research will also develop the parasite-bacteria system as a tool for teaching K-12 students, and train a Ph.D. student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parasites obtain their food from other organisms, thereby causing harm to these hosts. The ubiquity of harmful parasites in nature amplifies their impacts on individual hosts' health, as well as on ecosystems and environments. An individual host can be infected with multiple parasites at any given time and competition between parasites within a host is also common and likely influences both host and parasite ecology. Understanding these competitive interactions will influence our understanding of ecosystem function and health. In this study, we use the interactions that occur between species of Steinernematid insect-parasitic nematodes to model parasite competition. We assessed how bacteria that beneficially associate with individual nematode species can modulate this parasite competition through killing competitors of their nematode associate.

 

Intellectual Merit

Using the NSF DDIG, we assessed the competition that naturally occurs between Steinernema feltiae and S. affine nematodes within an insect host. We identified that S. affine nematodes have a competitive advantage over S. feltiae nematodes: when S. affine and S. feltiae nematodes infect the same insect only S. affine is able to reproduce. This competitive advantage is facilitated by the presence of Xenorhabdus bovienii bacteria that associate with S. affine nematodes. Our work established that the bacteria kill the competing nematode by causing an intestinal infection. This finding is important because it defines a new role for bacteria that beneficially associate with hosts: providing a competitive advantage to its host by killing the competitors. Such a competitive advantage could occur in other parasite competitions. Additionally, our finding that bacteria can modulate parasite competition raises the idea that to fully understand parasite competition and its impact on the environment, we must take into account the bacteria that associate with the parasites and the infected host.

Further work is currently being done to assess how the X. bovienii bacteria are able to kill S. feltiae nematodes. Such information may lead to new ways to control nematodes and other parasites. Parasite control strategies are important for advancements in agriculture, animal husbandry, and human health.

 

Broader Impacts

The findings from this study have been disseminated through seminars and presentations at the University of Wisconsin Madison campus as well as at a national meeting (The American Society of Microbiology General Meeting). Findings from this work are currently in the process of being published for more widespread use. Additionally, information from this work has been incorporated into K-12 outreach programs at the University of Wisconsin Madison (e.g. Expanding Your Horizons Conference for middle school girls). The NSF DDIG has provided the opportunity for training two graduate students new technologies, has significantly added to the thesis of one graduate student, and has provided access to new technologies for the laboratory. Further, it provided professional development opportunities for one graduate student, who organized a 2014 undergraduate summer research opportunity for 6 students, culminating in a Symbiosis Symposium (also organized by the student) featuring local invited speakers and a poster session including the participating undergraduate researchers, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows (See attached symposium announcement). The symposium attracted approximately 75 attendees. The graduate student mentored the undergraduates in appropriate conduct of research, hypothesis formulation, and developing final presentations.


Last Modified: 09/15/2015
Modified by: Heidi Goodrich-Blair
